serinfo.sername: CHGIS, Version: 4. Cambridge, MA (USA): Harvard Yenching Institute, Jan 2007

descript.abstract: point features showing towns & mountains on the routes north and south of the Tarim Basin, from Korla-Aksu and from Qarkilik-Khotan; digitized from H.M. Prezhavalsky "Map of Central Asia" 1884 (first version)CHGIS V4 also provides supplemental datasets, including points derived from Russian Historical Maps, and other features that have been developed or processed from publicly available sources for use with CHGIS layers. -- text from CHGIS v4 CD-ROM.
descript.purpose: Developed by Irina Merzliakova (Inst of Geography) and Alexei Karimov (Inst for the History of Science), Russian Academy of SciencesThe China Historical Geographic Information System (CHGIS) project is designed to provide a GIS platform for scholarly and scientific research. Considerable flexibility has been designed into the GIS, allowing for alternate versions and variations of feature attributes, spatial data, and competing political entities. The CHGIS aims to build a reliable database of administrative units and settlements, but does not wish to impose a closed interpretation on the relationships among those units. The advantage of creating the CHGIS, rather than printing paper maps, is that the relationships between the units can be modified and improved whenever new information becomes available and the new "edition" needs only to be posted on the Internet for users to download. The CHGIS editors have set high editorial standards for the inclusion of material in the CHGIS time series data and regulate the release of the official versions from designated CHGIS participating organizations. Users may search the database for administrative units and capitals for any given time in Chinese history, can create customized digital maps for particular times and places, or can join their own datasets for spatial analysis, thematic mapping, or other specialized statistical modeling according to their own interests.

theme.themekt: Alexandria Digital Library, CHGIS specialized feature type vocabularies
theme.themekey: towns and natural features, Tarim Basin, Xinjiang

idinfo.accconst: The CHGIS datasets are freely distributed for non-commercial academic research purposes. The datasets may be obtained by ordering a CD-ROM or downloaded free of charge from the CHGIS and HGL Web sites. Please consult the CHGIS Web site (http://fas.harvard.edu/~chgis) for additional details.
idinfo.useconst: Academic use of CHGIS data is allowed, and encouraged, provided that any derived data or digital images of maps give proper citation to CHGIS as stated above. The CHGIS datasets are distributed for non-commercial academic research purposes only. Any organization or individual that makes commercial or revenue generating use of the CHGIS Datasets must first obtain a licensing agreement from CHGIS Management Committee. Use of the datasets distributed on CD-ROM or downloaded from CHGIS websites implies acceptance of all the terms stated in the End User's License Agreement (http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~chgis/data/chgis/downloads/v4/EULA.txt), and acknowledges understanding of any liabilities stated therein by the end-user.
idinfo.datacred: CHGIS, Version: 4. Cambridge, MA (USA): Harvard Yenching Institute, Jan 2007.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.0.1324

procstep.procdesc: ArcMap was used to edit the source shape files and delete the values in any columns containing Chinese characters, then the ArcGIS 9.2 Feature Class to Feature Class tool was used to move the geographic shapes into SDE. Microsoft Access was used to import the CHGIS-provided text file containing the properly encoded attribute values. A new text file containing just attributes with Chinese characters was created with the proper encoding, either GBK or UTF-8 depending on the source. This text file was imported to a new table in Oracle using SQLLoader with the NLS_CHARACTERSET property set to either UTF8 or ZHS16GBK. The attributes were then joined back to the shapes using Windows SQLPlus with the NLS_LANGUAGE property set to Traditional Chinese. This process ensured that the encoding was properly interpreted during the import.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.
